text:
Anyone experiencing pagination issues with the `/contacts/v1/lists/` endpoint?
Pagination doesn't work for us anymore, attaching an example.
<@U02HMMBET6D> Oh, yes! Me too! My software service is in a terrible situation now...

I've created a post regarding this issue
<https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/APIs-Integrations/contacts-v1-lists-Pagination-doesn-t-work/td-p/665824>
<@U02HMMBET6D> Oh, thank you very much! It really helps…!
Thanks for looking <@U25PYL3Q8>
you’ve granted all the scopes, correct?
Yes. Every single one
I’ll trim that back soon, but I was trying to get this working
Other requests do seem to be working, btw, but this particular scope is not
yeah, that was going to be the second thing I asked
this is for custom objects, right? Are you able to read?
I’m not sure we actually read custom objects. Let me take a look
are you making these from an external server or like inside HubSpot (serverless/ops hub)
only in unit tests, it seems
From inside a Java app running in AWC/ECS
that integration test is disabled. I’m going to enable it and see what happpens
gotcha

I've got an issue with an operations hub Custom Code action.

Issue is that it's processing 4k + companies and updating them, and all too quickly hits the "secondly limit" timeout because HubSpot process a great deal of them in parallel. Which poses the question - isn't the feature basically useless for anything > 150 objects? Or am missing something?
OK, a GET for a custom object returned a 200

but POST returns
```com.deltav.HubSpot.exceptions.HubSpotApiException: CLIENT_ERROR: FORBIDDEN (403)  [url='POST <https://api.hubapi.com/crm/v3/objects/appointment>'], [body='{"status":"error","message":"This app hasn't been granted all required scopes to make this call. Read more about required scopes here: <https://developers.HubSpot.com/scopes>.","correlationId":"43a9d862-359b-4e93-9b07-5833c3194c94","errors":[{"message":"One or more of the following scopes are required.","context":{"requiredScopes":["crm.objects.custom.write"]}}],"links":{"scopes":"<https://developers.HubSpot.com/scopes>"},"category":"MISSING_SCOPES"}']```
That is from the integration test running on localhost

So.. Next I would delete all scopes then re-add just those two and test again..

Then I’m thinking I would create a new private app with just those two scopes, change out my secrets in the code and retest

I think at that point I would assume there is some sort of bug

I might also do a curl post so that I could be sure it wasn’t my code or the library that was causing this error
this seems really funky
heh, yeah
Maybe the curl first
good call. I’m using Open Feign to create the REST client, which is usually pretty reliable
I don’t have a curl with non api stuff saved anywhere otherwise I would send it to you
Thanks for the assist <@U25PYL3Q8>
I’ll try the curl, and if that fails, I’ll figure out how to submit a bug report
Pls, can someone confirm that the simple creation of a private app don't interfere in the current clients that use an API-Key??
So, interesting. I created a new private app with just those keys, and now it worked.
so weird
lol
so you switched the keys and the call 200 now?
yup
Not that I've ever seen. API keys are being retired soon though (you're probably aware).
I’m going to try and delete the custom object scopes from the original app, commit that change, add them back and try again on the original private app and see if that works
technology is so weird
that worked as well
nice job! at least we got it going
glitch in the matrix
how frustrating
:slightly_smiling_face:
thanks again!
Yep.. I'm aware! Thx for you answer!
Can you use v3?

You can do the checking on your calls to get your timeout /limit settings and address the issue there (best solution), however I believe that these timeouts inside operations hub are queued to be processed later

When I first started having issues like this, I exported a variable in the callback from the code if this was an issue, and then I placed them into a list and did the processing again like 10 minutes later (this was based on how these were usually processing) and then did this a final time, basically with a third list and sending them back through the same workflow like that

It was a bit of silly work around, but I was fresh in ops hub and was just seeing what was possible
yeah, that shouldn’t affect anything, api keys are like “site wide” where as a private app key is only for that app — so they shouldn’t interfere with each other at all
But if you put in a 30 second wait, don't they all delay in parallel?
yes correct, excatly why I ended up creating like three pass through so that it would process all like 900 that were getting updated. The best way is using the limit response in the code…
Yes, i also understand it like this. Thx Nicholas!
Technically it would interfere with rate limits. But it wouldn't interfere with the core functionality
very true!

>  But if you put in a 30 second wait, don’t they all delay in parallel?
You might get better behavior with a random component in the wait time, so that stochastically the calls _roughly_ obey the rate limit.

Napkin math: If your burst limit is 150 calls per ten seconds and you have 4k companies to update, those calls have to be spread over 27 ten-second intervals (approx 5 minutes).

If you randomly assign each call a delay 0 ≤ t ≤ 270 seconds, most of the calls should succeed on their first go.
HubSpot’s retry logic probably handles 429 errors nicely, but I’m not sure if it staggers the retries to avoid them all happening at once.
